snippet: With China’s once-a-decade leadership transition nearing, Communist Party leaders are pushing back against what some see as military officials’ intrusion into policy and politics.
abstract: China’s Communist Party leaders, with the country's once-a-decade leadership transition nearing, are pushing back against what some see as military intrusion into policy and politics; they are conducting a highly visible campaign against disloyalty and corruption, even requiring all officers to report financial assets; Pres Hu Jintao has been building a network of army loyalists (Series: Changing of the Guard).

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
byline.contributor: Edward Wong reported from Beijing and Singapore, and Jonathan Ansfield from Beijing. Patrick Zuo contributed research.

lead_paragraph: With China’s once-a-decade leadership transition nearing, Communist Party leaders are pushing back against what some see as military officials’ intrusion into policy and politics.

headline.print_headline: Military Seeks More Sway In China, Worrying Party
headline.seo: China’s Military Seeks More Sway, Worrying Communist Party
headline.main: Party Bristles at Military’s Push for More Sway in China
